subsection.title: Introduction
subsection.p: We have seen that an equation of the form \sin \theta = k (for -1 \lt k \lt 1) always has two solutions between 0 and 2\pi . For example, the figure below illustrates that x=\dfrac{\pi}{6} and x=\dfrac{5\pi}{6} are solutions of the equation \sin x = 0.5. These two solutions correspond to the two points on the unit circle where y=0.5.

The calculator gives us only one of these solutions, but we can use reference angles to find the other solution. In fact, if we use a calculator to find one solution as \theta_{1}=\sin^{-1}k, then the other solution is \theta_{2}=\pi - \theta_{1}. You can see this by considering the symmetry of the sine graph, or of the unit circle, as shown below.
This relationship between the two solutions still holds if k is negative, because the calculator returns a negative angle for \theta_{1}=\sin^{-1}k. See the figure below.

note.p: Why is \pi - \theta greater than \theta in the figure above? Think about negative numbers: if \theta is a negative number, then \pi - \theta is greater than \theta. For example, if \theta=\dfrac{-\pi}{4}, then \pi - \theta=\pi - \dfrac{-\pi}{4}=\pi + \dfrac{\pi}{4}=\dfrac{5\pi}{4}

Solutions of \cos nx=k
Repeat part (1) for y=\cos x and y=0.6.
Repeat part (2) for y=\cos x and y=-0.6.
Repeat part (3) for y=\cos 2x and y=0.6.

solution.p: The calculator gives us the solution \sin^{-1}(-0.58)=-0.6187 However, because this solution is not between 0 and 2\pi, we find a coterminal angle, \theta_{1}=\sin^{-1}(-0.58)+2\pi = -0.6187+2\pi=5.6645 for the solution in the fourth quadrant. The second quadrant solution is \theta_2=\pi-\sin^{-1}(-0.58)=\pi +0.6187=3.7603 To four decimal places, the desired solutions are 3.7603 and 5.6645.

subsection.p: A similar method applies to equations of the form \cos \theta = k. The two solutions between 0 and 2\pi are \theta_{1}=\cos^{-1}(k) and \theta_{2}=2\pi -\cos^{-1}(k). Once again, you can see this by considering the symmetry of the cosine graph, or of the unit circle, as shown belo
The relationship between the two solutions still holds if k is negative. See the figure below.
Equations of the form \tan \theta = k are generally easier to solve, because there is only one solution in each cycle of the graph. Each solution differs from the previous one by \pi, as shown below.

For example, to solve the equation \tan \theta = -2.4 for 0 \le \theta \lt 2\pi, we first calculate \tan^{-1}(-2.4)=-1.1760 Because this angle is not between 0 and 2\pi, we add \pi to find the next two solutions:
\theta_{1}\amp = -1.1760+\pi=1.9656 \theta_{2}\amp = 1.9656+\pi=5.1072
We summarize these observations for the three trigonometric functions as follows.

ol.li: The equation \cos \theta = k, ~~ -1\lt k \lt 1, has two solutions between 0 and 2\pi: \theta_{1}=\cos^{-1}(k)~~ \text{and}~~ \theta_{2}=2\pi -\theta_{1}

subsection.title: Multiple Solutions

statement.p: Find all solutions of ~~\sin 2x=0.5~~ between 0 and 2\pi.

solution.p: We begin as usual, by taking the inverse sine of each side of the equation, to get 2x=\sin^{-1}(0.5) There are two values of 2x between 0 and 2\pi with \sin 2x=0.5 namely 2x=\dfrac{\pi}{6} and 2x=\pi - \dfrac{\pi}{6}=\dfrac{5\pi}{6}. Solving these equations for x yields x=\dfrac{\pi}{12} and x=\dfrac{5\pi}{12}.

ol.li: Sketch a graph of ~~y=\cos 2x~~ for 0 \le \theta \le 2\pi.
Find exact values for all solutions of \cos 2x=\dfrac{-\sqrt{2}}{2} between 0 and 2\pi.

subsection.p: As we observed earlier, equations involving the tangent function are easier to solve, because there is only one solution in each cycle of the graph. Once we have found one solution, we can find all the others by adding multiples of the period.

statement.p: Find all solutions of ~~\tan 2t=-1~~ between 0 and 2\pi.

sidebyside.p: We expect to find four solutions between 0 and 2\pi. The first angle 2t between 0 and 2\pi whose tangent is 1 is 2t=\dfrac{3\pi}{4}, so the first solution is t_{1}=\dfrac{3\pi}{8}. Now, the period of the graph of y=\tan 2t is \dfrac{\pi}{2}, as shown at right.

statement.p: Find all solutions of ~~\tan 2x=\sqrt{3}~~ between 0 and 2\pi.

subsection.p: The larger the value of n, the more cycles the graph completes between 0 and 2\pi, and the more solutions we find. Thus, for -1 \lt k \lt 1, there are six solutions of \sin 3x=k between 0 and 2\pi, eight solutions of \sin 4x=k, and so on. (See the figure below.)

subsection.title: Using a Calculator for Multiple Solutions
subsection.p: Of course, if k is not one of the special values, we'll need a calculator to help us solve the equation.

solution.p: We first solve for the trig ratio, \cos 2x 1+4\cos 2x \amp = 2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Subtract 1 from both sides.}} 4\cos 2x \amp = 1 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 4.}} \cos 2x \amp = 0.25 Next, we use a calculator to find two solutions of \cos 2x=0.25. The solutions of this equation, rounded to three decimal places, are 2x \amp = 1.318 \amp\amp \text{and} \amp 2x \amp = 4.965 x_{1} \amp = 0.659 \amp\amp \amp x_{2}\amp =2.483 Finally, because the period of the function f(x)=\cos 2x is \pi, we can find the other two solutions by adding \pi to the first two solutions, to get x_{3}\amp=0.659+\pi = 3.801 x_{4}\amp=2.483+\pi=5.624 To two decimal places, the four solutions are 0.66, 2.48, 3.80, and 5.62

subsection.title: Using a Substitution
subsection.p: For more complicated equations, it can be helpful to use a substitution, in order to reduce the equation to the form \sin \theta=k (or \cos \theta=k or \tan \theta=k). We want our substitution to replace the input of the sine function by a single variable. For example, in the next example, we substitute \theta for the angle 2x+1.5, so that the equation \sin (2x+1.5)=-0.3 becomes \sin \theta = -0.3.

statement.p: Use a substitution to solve ~~\sin (2x+1.5)=-0.3~~ for 0 \le x \le 2\pi.

solution.p: We expect to find four solutions. Let \theta = 2x+1.5, and use a calculator to find two solutions of \sin \theta = -0.3. The solutions, rounded to three decimal places, are \theta_{1}=\sin^{-1}(-0.3)=-0.3047 ~~ \text{and} ~~ \theta_{2}=\pi - \sin^{-1}(-0.3)=3.4463 Because \theta is not between 0 and 2\pi, we find a coterminal angle, \theta_{1}=\sin^{-1}(-0.3)+2\pi = 5.9785 Next we replace \theta by 2x+1.5 to find two of the solutions of the original equation: 2x+1.5 \amp = 3.4463 \amp\amp \text{and} \amp 2x+1.5 \amp = 5.9785 x_{1} \amp = 0.9731 \amp\amp \amp x_{2}\amp =2.2392 Finally, because the period of the function f(x)=\sin (2x+1.5) is \pi, we find the other two solutions by adding \pi to the first two solutions, to get x_{3}\amp=0.9731+\pi = 4.1147 x_{4}\amp=2.2392+\pi=5.3808 Rounded to hundredths, the four solutions are 0.97, 2.24, 4.11, and 5.38.

statement.p: Use a substitution to solve ~~4\cos (3x-0.5) = -3.2~~ for 0 \le x \le 2\pi.

subsection.p: Here is our strategy for solving trigonometric equations by using a substitution.

assemblage.title: Using a Substitution to Solve Trigonometric Equations

ol.li: Substitute \theta = Bx+C, and find two solutions for \sin \theta = k or \cos \theta = k.
Replace \theta by Bx+C in each solution, and solve for x.
Find the other solutions by adding multiples of \dfrac{2\pi}{B} to the first two solutions.
Substitute \theta = Bx+C, and find one solution for \tan \theta = k.
Replace \theta by Bx+C and solve for x.
Find the other solutions by adding multiples of \dfrac{\pi}{B} to the first solution.

statement.p: Find all solutions between 0 and 2\pi to ~~5+0.4\tan (3x-0.5)=4.5.

solution.p: The graph of f(x)=5+0.4\tan (3x-0.5) completes six cycles between 0 and 2\pi, so we expect to find six solutions, as illustrated below. We'll use the substitution \theta=3x-0.5 to reduce the equation to 5+0.4\tan \theta)=4.5. Next, we isolate the trig ratio. Subtract 5 from both sides of the equation, then divide by 0.4.

Replacing \theta by 3x-0.5, we find the first solution. 3x-0.5 \amp = -0.8960 3x\amp = -0.3960 x \amp = -0.1320 This value of x is not between 0 and 2\pi, but because the period of f(x) is \dfrac{\pi}{3}, we can add \dfrac{\pi}{3} \approx 1.0472 to any solution to find another solution.
x_{1} \amp =-0.1320+1.0472=0.9152 x_{2} \amp =0.9152+1.0472=1.9624 x_{3} \amp =1.9624+1.0472=3.0096 x_{4} \amp =3.0096+1.0472=4.0568 x_{5} \amp =4.0568+1.0472=5.1040 x_{6} \amp =5.1040+1.0472=6.1512
We stop here, because the next solution is greater than 2\pi. Rounded to two decimal places, the six solutions are 0.92, 1.96, 3.01, 4.06, 5.10, and 6.15.

Find all solutions of 2-4\tan 3(x+0.2)=5 between 0 and 2\pi. Round your answers to two decimal places.

subsection.title: Applications
subsection.p: Trigonometric equations often arise in the study of periodic models.

statement.p: A piston is pumping vertically at a rate of 1000 cycles per second. The distance between its lowest and highest position is 16 centimeters.

ol.li: Suppose the piston is at its midline position at t=0 and moving downwards. Find a formula for the sinusoidal function h(t) that gives the piston's height.
Use the formula to find the first two times the piston is 14 centimeters above its lowest position.

li.p: Because the piston starts at its midline and moves down, we will write h(y) as a sine function: h(t)=-A\sin (Bt) + k The amplitude is A=\dfrac{16}{2} = 8, and the midline is k=8. The period is \dfrac{1}{1000}, so \dfrac{B}{1000} = 2\pi, and B=2000\pi. Thus h(t)=-8\sin (2000\pi t) + 8

sidebyside.p: The graph is shown at right.

statement.p: A lever on an oil well is pumping vertically at a rate of 10 cycles per minute. The distance between its lowest position at the ground and its highest position is 1.8 meters.

ol.li: Suppose the lever is at its midline position at t=0 and moving downwards. Find a formula for the sinusoidal function h(t) that gives the lever's height.
Find the first two times that lever is 1 meter above its lowest position.
0.0518 minutes and 0.9823 minutes
